noun.description: The upper part of the human body, or the front or upper part of the body of an animal, typically separated from the rest of the body by a neck, and containing the brain, mouth, and sense organs.
A thing resembling a head either in form or in relation to a whole.
The front, forward, or upper part or end of something.
A person in charge of something; a director or leader.
examples: the head of the Dutch Catholic Church

noun.description: A person considered as a numerical unit.
examples: they paid fifty dollars a head

noun.description: A component in an audio, video, or information system by which information is transferred from an electrical signal to the recording medium, or vice versa.
A body of water kept at a particular height in order to provide a supply at sufficient pressure.
examples: an 8 m head of water in the shafts

noun.description: A toilet or bathroom on a boat or ship.
The word that governs all the other words in a phrase in which it is used, having the same grammatical function as the whole phrase.
A superficial deposit of rock fragments, formed at the edge of an ice sheet by repeated freezing and thawing and then moved downhill.

verb.description: Be in the leading position on.
examples: the Palm Sunday procession was headed by the crucifer

verb.description: Give a title or caption to.
examples: an article headed “The Protection of Human Life.”
he was heading for the exit
we were headed in the wrong direction

verb.description: Shoot or pass (the ball) with the head.
examples: a corner kick that he headed into the net

verb.description: Lop off the upper part or branches of (a plant or tree).
(of a lettuce or cabbage) form a head.

phrases: Big organizations exist because there are economies of scale, or because - as Ronald Coase pointed out in this classic paper - it's more efficient to run things by banging people's heads together than by haggling over contracts.

We were inches away and if he had not taken that initiative - something John is very good at - of knocking people's heads together and forcing them to come to an agreement to settle matters or to say we cannot make an agreement, that would not have been done.
This lying, prevarication and knocking people's heads together is standard practice.
I just think it's fun to knock people's heads together and call attention to how silly arguing over NOTHING can be.
You felt you were banging your head against a brick wall.
he ran up the road to head off approaching cars
Last night fans watched as Dev raced to head Maya off as part of his quest to free Sunita from prison after she was framed by his former fiancée.
I volunteered to go down the steep bank with Newby to head the lion off while Ruth and Husseman took the high route.
I try to head him off, but eventually he gets past me and jumps on Jarvis again, snarling and growling again.
He spied David making his way towards the car lot, a bottle in his hand, and moved to head him off, catching up with him just outside the exit.
origin: Old English hēafod, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hoofd and German Haupt.
